Authors: Pane M.M., Siregar C., Lake S.C.J.M.
Title: The Role of Big Data in Enhancing Student's Sustainable Development Awareness: A Case Study in Higher Education
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication Program, Communication Dept., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Siregar, C., Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication Program, Communication Dept., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Lake, S.C.J.M., Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication Program, Communication Dept., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This study objective is to find the general picture of the knowledge, attitude and behavior of students for sustainable development. It used the quantitative method with 160 students as the research subjects with the data collection technique of questionnaire distribution. The questionnaires are valid (the corrected item total correlations for knowledge, attitudes and behavior are: 0.745, 0.878 and 0.726) and reliable (α for knowledge, attitudes and behavior are: 0.985, 0.978 and 0.959). The positive nuances questionnaire's results are analyzed through a correlative analysis. The results showed scale 4 were chosen most for knowledge and attitude (41.40% and 42.93%), only in behavior the scale 3 was the most chosen (34.63%). The results concluded that the students tend to have positive knowledge, attitude and behavior towards the sustainable development, and the results will give strong support the sustainable future for human security. The results were connected with the big data, especially in social media and instant messaging where they can learn and get educated about sustainable development. © 2020 ACM.
Author Keywords: attitude; behavior; big data; instant messaging; Knowledge; social media; sustainable development
Index Keywords: Planning; Students; Surveys; Sustainable development; Correlative analysis; Data collection; Higher education; Human securities; Instant messaging; Quantitative method; Research subjects; Social media; Big data

Authors: Pane M.M., Siregar C., Rumeser J.A.A.
Title: The Role of Big Data for Interactive Online Learning: A Case Study in Students' Participations and Perceptions
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication Program, Communication Department, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Siregar, C., Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication Program, Communication Department, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Abstract: The study aimed to gain the performance of students' participations and perceptions in interactive online learning and to understand the role of big data in enhancing it. The study adapted the quantitative method. The respondents amounted 201 students of more than five departments with a different range of semesters. The study measured the participations and perceptions of the respondents when doing teamwork virtually using the online learning management system with the Likert scale on the scale of 1 to 5 with corrected item-total correlations 0.472, and α 0.613 (> 0.5). The performance of it is moderate to low for most of respondents. © 2020 ACM.
Author Keywords: Big data; learning management system; online learning; participations; perceptions
Index Keywords: Big data; Human resource management; Students; Likert scale; Online learning; Quantitative method; E-learning

Authors: Siregar C., Pane M.M., Anwar R.
Title: Pancasila, ethos respect, and anti-hoaxes on internet-based social media
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication, Comm. Dept., Faculty of Economics and Comunication, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center, Computer Science Dept., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Siregar, C., Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication, Comm. Dept., Faculty of Economics and Comunication, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Computer Science Dept., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Anwar, R., Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication, Comm. Dept., Faculty of Economics and Comunication, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: In its rapid development, social media does not only produces positive impacts, but also the negative ones. As information spreads quickly and broadly, so does hoax. The information filtering proccess has become more difficult. This study aims to get a comprehensive description on how the values of Pancasila, as have been taught in the Character Building: Pancasila (CB: Pancasila) courses, and of Respect in the ethos of "S.P.I.R.I.T" (Striving of Excellence, Perseverance, Integrity, Respect, Innovation and Teamwork), which is related to Ubinus'culture, has impacted the students of Bina Nusantara University (UBinus). This research is conducted on 185 Binusian 2021 students, selected from various departments. The result of questionnaire with Likert scale shows that 96.76% of the total respondents have positive speech, attitudes, and behavior in establishing communication in cyberspace (internet-based social media), while 03.24% are neutral. And none of them involved in spreading hoaxes through social media. © 2019 Association for Computing Machinery.
Author Keywords: Ethos respect; Hoax; Pancasila; Social media
Index Keywords: Information filtering; Speech communication; Cyberspaces; Ethos respect; Hoax; Internet based; Likert scale; Pancasila; Social media; Social networking (online)

Authors: Siregar C., Pane M.M., Ruman Y.S.
Title: The virtual team performance in solving teamwork conflict problems
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University Jalan Anggrek, Cakra No.1A, Kebon Jeruk, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Siregar, C., Bina Nusantara University Jalan Anggrek, Cakra No.1A, Kebon Jeruk, Jakarta, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Bina Nusantara University Jalan Anggrek, Cakra No.1A, Kebon Jeruk, Jakarta, Indonesia; Ruman, Y.S., Bina Nusantara University Jalan Anggrek, Cakra No.1A, Kebon Jeruk, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This study aimed to know the ability of Binus Online Learning (BOL) students as a virtual team in solving their teamwork conflict problems, especially when they have to complete team assignments. This study uses Tuckman theory of teamwork (known as team stages model or FSNP) as the main theoretical basis for reference [1, 2]. This study uses a quantitative method with interview randomly among the students to clarify the subject matter mainly focuses on 131 students as the respondents which are identified as the millennial generation (born 1981-2000, based on Reeves and Oh, 2008)[3] considering their fluency in using Information and Communication Technology (ICT). To measure the ability of respondents in solving teamwork conflict problems based on online learning system in BOL, Likert scale is used on a scale of 1 to 5 with corrected item-total correlations 0.49, and α 0.81 (> 0.5). The result shows scale 1 was chosen by 17.20%, scale 2 was 15.53%, scale 3 was 31.90%, scale 4 was 24.99%, and scale 5 was selected by 10.28% of respondents. It concluded that the virtual team performance of BOL in solving teamwork conflict problems is average (tend to be moderate to high). © 2018 Association for Computing Machinery.
Author Keywords: Binus online learning; Learning management system.; Solving teamwork conflict problems; Virtual team performance
Index Keywords: E-learning; Education computing; Human resource management; Students; Information and Communication Technologies; Learning management system; On-line learning systems; Online learning; Quantitative method; Solving teamwork conflict problems; Team assignment; Virtual team; Problem solving

Authors: Pane M.M., Siregar C., Ruman Y.S., Rumeser J.A.A.
Title: The application of the Lencioni model in online learning: A case study in higher education
Affiliations: Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Communication Science, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Siregar, C., Communication Science, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Ruman, Y.S., Communication Science, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The study aimed to understand the performance of students‟ abilities of leadership in conflict solving problems for undertaking the virtual teamwork in online learning using the Lencioni Model. The study adapted the quantitative method. The respondents amounted 131 students of four departments from online learning program with a different range of semesters. The study measured the teamwork effectiveness performance associated to the Lencioni Model of the respondents using the online learning management system with the Likert scale on the scale of 1 to 5 with corrected item-total correlations 0.49, and α 0.81 (> 0.5). The performance of teamwork effectiveness is moderate for most of respondents. It concludes that the teamwork abilities in the virtual teamwork of online learning students in Binus pinpoint on the awareness of the five dysfunctions of a team contribution using the Lencioni Model. © 2018 Association for Computing Machinery.
Author Keywords: Online learning; Teamwork effectiveness; The Lencioni Model; Virtual teamwork
Index Keywords: Education computing; Human resource management; Students; Conflict solving; Higher education; Likert scale; Online learning; Quantitative method; Teamwork effectiveness; Virtual teamwork; E-learning

Authors: Pane M.M., Ruman Y.S., Irawan I.
Title: The role of instant messaging in building virtual teamwork: A case study of character education in Binus University
Source title: Proceedings - 2017 10th International Conference on Human System Interactions, HSI 2017
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Character Building Development Center, BINA NUSANTARA University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Management Department, Character Building Development Center, BINA NUSANTARA University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Computer Science Department, Character Building Development Center, BINA NUSANTARA University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Ruman, Y.S., Management Department, Character Building Development Center, BINA NUSANTARA University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Irawan, I., Computer Science Department, Character Building Development Center, BINA NUSANTARA University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Teamwork is considered as an important competency in the era of information technology. Communications are predominantly doing virtually. The study aims to measure the role of instant messaging in building vitual teamwork. The study posited convenience sampling technique and quantitative method-based applying the measurement of frequency for managing and interpreting the data. The respondents involved students of sophomores, 5th and 7th semester students. The study populated 120 respondents consisting of students from many department such as Information Technology, Psychology, Visual Communication Design-Animation, Business Law, and Information System, Accounting-IS, IS-Management, Accounting, International Relations, English Literature, Game Application Technology (GAT), and Marketing Communication. It measured the teamwork competencies performance of the respondents using the instant messaging using the Likert scale on the scale of 1 to 5. The performance is: scale 4 is chosen by 40.05% respondents, scale 3 is 29.35%, the scale 2 is 14.12%, the scale 5 is 12.27%, and the scale 1 is just chosen by 4.21% of respondents. The result of the study indicated that the role of instant messaging (IM) discorded with expected role. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Character education; Instant messaging; Virtual teamwork
Index Keywords: Animation; E-learning; Education; Information management; Marketing; Message passing; Visual communication; Application technologies; Instant messaging; International relations; Marketing communications; Quantitative method; Sampling technique; Virtual teamwork; Visual communication designs; Students

Authors: Pane M.M., Siregar C., Sriyanto H.
Title: Conflict problem solving in digital technology: A case study in virtual teamwork for online learning
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III no. 45, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III no. 45, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Siregar, C., Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III no. 45, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Sriyanto, H., Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III no. 45, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Abstract: Considering that the virtual teamwork has rapidly emerging, the phenomenon turns out to create another problem, the internal team conflict. To increase the effectiveness of teamwork, the conflict problem must be solved. This study aimed to know the performance of students? abilities of conflict solving problems in doing the virtual teamwork in online learning. It was taken using convenience and using the quantitative method. The respondents are online learning students from varied semesters. There are 97 respondents consisting of students from several departments, i.e.: Information System, Business Management, Marketing Management, and Computer Science. It measured the conflict problem solving abilities performance of the respondents using the online learning management system with the Likert scale on the scale of 1 to 5 with corrected item total correlations 0.49, and α 0.81 (> 0.5). The performance is : scale 3 is chosen by 31.15% of respondents, scale 4 is 25.64%, the scale 2 is 16.40%, the scale 1 is 17.58%, and the scale 5 is just chosen by 8.87% of respondents. © 2017 Association for Computing Machinery.
Author Keywords: Conflict problem solving; Learning management system; Online learning; Virtual teamwork
Index Keywords: E-learning; Education; Educational technology; Human resource management; Information management; Marketing; Students; Business management; Digital technologies; Learning management system; Marketing management; Online learning; Problem-solving abilities; Quantitative method; Virtual teamwork; Problem solving

Title: The potent role of information technology in todays Indonesian democracy
Source title: 2017 3rd International Conference on Information Management, ICIM 2017
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ruman, Y.S., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: This article shows that information technology has been advanced as an instrument for democracy in Indonesia. It means that democracy is now not only depending on the formal institution like a political party or legislative institution. This elite model and conventional of citizen participation has moved to a populist model by information technology. On one hand, every citizen by individually or collectively could participate in anywhere or time to influence the public policy. They also interact actively to their political leader, their represent or government in whole. And then, on the other hand, the government could deliver the public policies directly and quickly. By using the subjective meaning methodology, this article will describe how the information technology influences the political elite on one hand and citizens on the other hand in Indonesia politics. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Information management; Social sciences; Citizen participation; Democracy; Digital; Indonesia; Political parties; Potent role; Representative; Public policy

Authors: Pane M.M., Lake S.C.J.M., Patriana R.
Title: Teamwork competency mapping of ubinus student toward the ASEAN economic community
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KemanggisanIlir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KemanggisanIlir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Lake, S.C.J.M., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KemanggisanIlir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Patriana, R., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KemanggisanIlir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This study aims to map the extent of teamwork ability of Bina Nusantara University students to face the era of the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC). Respondents selected studies were Binusian 2017 (5th semester student). Respondents amounted to 482 people from five departments: Psychology, Computer Science, Management, Accounting, and Marketing Communication. The research results are processed using SPSS. The normality test showed P <0_05, participants’ mean score 87.78 and standard deviation 13,075. The results showed that 362 respondents (75.1%) have the ability to teamwork in moderate level, 68 (14.11%) in the high level, and 52 (10.79%) in the lower level. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.

Authors: Ch R.P., Irawan I., Pane M.M.
Title: Self awareness mapping of Ubinus students toward the national culture based on the values of PANCASILA (3rd principle: Unity of Indonesia)
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ch, R.P., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Irawan, I., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Facing the globalization era, the younger generation should understand of the importance of self-awareness towards national culture based on the values of Pancasila, especially the 3rd principle. This study used qualitative research method, which is analytical description of the results of the written interview and FGD. This research aims to find the mapping/overview of self-awareness of BINUSIAN 2018 toward the national culture based on the values of Pancasila (3rd principle, Unity of Indonesia) and create instructional learning model, especially Pancasila values. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Mapping/Overview; Self-Awareness; The Values of Pancasila (3rd Principle, Unity of Indonesia)

Authors: Pane M.M., Rumeser J.A.A., Sriyanto H.
Title: The performance of SECI model implementation by Binus students in the environmental awareness socialization final project
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Psychology Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Psychology Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sriyanto, H., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Environmental matters is one of the big problems in Jakarta as the capital city. That is the reason why Binus University took part with a project called ‘environmental awareness socialization’ as an action to educate the society around Binus and the students as well. Before educating the society around Binus, who were done by several groups of the students, the students, called The Cleanliness Ambassador Program, must have the values of environmental awareness first. To have the values internalized, the students had to do this project using the SECI (Socialization, Externalization, Combination, Internalization) model, to transfer their knowledge about clean environment each other effectively as well as strengthen their teamwork. This study aimed to find the performance of the students while doing the project using the SECI model. Participants of this study were 100 undergraduate students who took CB-Spiritual Development subject (Binusian 2017) with this particular final project. This study taken using convenience sampling technique and used quantitative method by using the measurement of frequency for managing and interpreting the data. This study found that the performance of SECI model done for the stage S, E, C, and I, the highest is 77%, medium is 18%, and the lowest score is 6%. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Environmental awareness socialization project; SECI model
References: Ahmad, M., (2014) International Journal of Information Processing and Management (IJIPM), 5, p. 28; Aronson, E., Wilson, T.D., Akert, R.M., (2013) Social Psychology, , 8th edn., Pearson, USA; Gourlay, S., The SECI Model of Knowledge Creation: Some Empirical Shortcomings (2004) 4Th European Conference on Knowledge Management, pp. 1-10. , http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/sngourlay/PDFs/Gourlay%202004%20SECI.pdf, Conference Proceedings Published by Academic Conferences Ltd 0954457722, December 2015; Grzybowska, K., Gajdzik, B., (2013) Metalurgija, 52, p. 275; Nonaka, I., Takeuchi, H., (2005) The Knowledge Creating Company, , Oxford University Press, Oxford; Stillweell, W.D., The Polanyi Society Periodical, 30. , 2003–2004

Authors: Sasmoko, Herisetyantri I., Suroso J.S., Harisno, Ying Y., Rosalin K., Chairiyani R.P., Pane M.M., Permai S.D.
Title: Am I a well being teacher? (A review of subjective wellbeing for elementary teachers)
Authors with affiliations: Sasmoko, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Herisetyantri, I., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Suroso, J.S., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Harisno, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Ying, Y., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Rosalin, K., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Chairiyani, R.P., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Permai, S.D., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: One of Indonesia's government efforts to enhance the quality of education is to do certification program and qualification test for teachers. These programs are expected to have a positive outcome which is a better and increased teachers' competence. On the other hand, teacher's well-being might be disturbed by a negative impact from the program. This research aims to seek the subjective wellbeing of teachers in Jakarta and how to help teachers reach its wellbeing. The method use Neuroresearch (mix method), a mixture of qualitative research to build a theoretical construct and also observation as well as in-depth interviews with various parties and quantitative method by using measurement instruments subjective well-being Likert scale. The results found that (1) elementary teachers tend heading to wellbeing significantly at á <0.05 and (2) the cognitive dimension of teachers is an absolute determinant in shaping the well-being of primary school teachers. When a teachers cognitive is improved, then the wellbeing of primary school teachers will be increased by 20.983 from the current conditions. The study also found that the cognitive dimension is determined by the role of family situations and affective quality of teachers capable of acting 13.150 alters cognitive quality teachers. Recommendation from the results of this research is the need for new policies to change the model of teacher competency test that can empower cognitive competencies and simultaneously improve the conditions of teacher's family as the foundation of its economy. © Serials Publications.

Authors: Willyarto M.N., Pane M., Chairiyani R.
Title: Mathematics learning method of bar modeling for elementary school students
Authors with affiliations: Willyarto, M.N., Bina Nusantara University11530, Indonesia; Pane, M., Bina Nusantara University11530, Indonesia; Chairiyani, R., Bina Nusantara University11530, Indonesia
Abstract: Discrepancy of knowledge among students, teachers and schools to some extent has contributed in developing the negative attitude that says mathematics is hard. Therefore, the author tries to explain a method for teaching mathematics (especially for elementary school students), to be easily understood by students. As a result, mathematics is no longer perceived hard. One good method of learning mathematics is the use of models (bar modeling). The author conducted research by providing two different treatments, without bar modeling and with bar modeling, to the elementary school students. The result showed that the use of bar modeling has increased students’ scores significantly. Bar modeling is not the only method of teaching at the elementary level, and it is easier for elementary school students in learning mathematical concepts of symbolization in problem solving. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers.
References: Abdurrahman, M., (1999) Pendidikan Bagi Anak berkesulitan Belajar, , Penerbit Rineka Cipta, Jakarta; Dick, W., Carey, L., Carey, J.O., (2005) The Systematic Design of Instruction, , Pearson, Boston; Eric, C.C., (2009) Journal of Science and Mathematics, p. 36; FitzSimmons, J.A., http://plato.wilmington.edu:http://plato.wilmington.edu/faculty/jfitzs/tchg_phi.htm, plato.wilmington.edu., Retrieved April 1, 2010; Gredler, M.E., (2001) Learning and Instruction: Theory Into Practice, , 4th edn., Merrill Prentice Hall, Ohio; Hadi, S., Mathematics Education Reform Movement In Indonesia (2012) 12th International Congress on Mathematical Education, , COEX, Seoul, Korea; Hardiman, F.B., (2007) Filsafat Modern, , Gramedia, Jakarta; Smith, P.L., Ragan, T.J., (1993) Instructional Design, , Merill, New York; Wyatt, W., http://arapaho.nsuok.edu:http://arapaho.nsuok.edu/∼wyattw/webfiles/philosophy.html, arapaho.nsuok.edu., Retrieved April 1, 2010

Authors: Fios F., Pane M.M., Tirtawinata C.M.
Title: Self development education has no correlation to self esteem of Bina Nusantara University students
Authors with affiliations: Fios, F., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Tirtawinata, C.M., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: Self Development in education is an urgent aspect of human being. At Bina Nusantara University of Jakarta there is a self development education to develop the personality of students in their mind, body, soul and heart. Through this course namely character building (self development series), students arranged to know their selves well and holistically. This research wants to know how the impact of self development education on the students, especially in self esteem aspect. This study is using quantitative method. The results of field research on 336 students showed a negative correlation between Self-Esteem and Self-Knowledge (correlation = −0.257, P = 0,00, P < 0, 05). That is, the higher the self-esteem of students, the lower the knowledge about themselves. Self development education has no correlation to the self esteem of Bina Nusantara University Students. It is an interesting finding. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers.
Author Keywords: Bina Nusantara University; Education; Self development; Self esteem; Students
References: Cooper, R., (1998) Executive EQ: Emotional Intelligence in Leadership and Organizations, , Barkley Publishing Group, New York; (2010) Character Building: Self Development Education, , Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta; De Janasz, S.C., Dowd, K.O., Schneider, B.Z., (2009) Interpersonal Skill in Organization, 12p. , Mc Graw Hill, Singapore; De Janasz, S.C., Dowd, K.O., Schneider, B.Z., (2009) Interpersonal Skill in Organization, 5p. , Mc Graw Hill, Singapore; Wilson, R.A., (1996) Character Above All, , Simon and Schuster Inc., New York

Authors: Patriana Ch R., Irawan I., Tampubolon S., Pane M.M.
Title: Benefits of using smartphones for improving students’ learning outcomes at BINUS University
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Patriana Ch, R., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Irawan, I., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Tampubolon, S., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to find out the benefits of using smartphones for improving students’ learning outcomes. This research was based on the quantitative approach and Baker’s theory on Smartphone usage (2005). Data collection was conducted by distributing questionnaires. The questionnaires were constructed by the researchers based on the theory of Baker (2005), involving 200 students of BINUS University. Data analysis was performed by Pearson correlation analysis. The results of this study are there is a positive correlation between portability and motivation (r = 0.335, p < 0.01), a positive correlation between collaboration and motivation (r = 0.342, p < 0.01). There is no correlation between age and motivation either no correlation between GPA and motivation (r = − 0.067, p > 0.05). These results are expected to give impacts on the teaching methods of the lecturers in order to help improve their students’ learning outcomes. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers.

Title: The mediating role of social competition identity management strategy in the predictive relationship between susceptibility to social influence, internet privacy concern, and online political efficacy
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Psychology Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Abraham, J., Psychology Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: There are few psychotechnological researches in political world in Indonesia, whereas Indonesia will enter "Year of Politics" by General Election which will be held in 2014. This research aimed at examining the hypothesis of predictive correlation, at the individual level, between susceptibility to social influence, internet privacy concern (as predictor variables) and online political efficacy (as the dependent variable). This research hypothesized that the relationship between the variables is mediated by online identity management strategy in the form of social competition. This research employed questionnaire to gain variables data. Participants of this research were 214 undergraduate students of Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta (106 males, 108 females). Result of this research shows that five of seven proposed hypotheses are supported by empirical data. Implications of the result of this research for online system development for political activities are discussed in the end of this article. © 2014 IFIP International Federation for Information Processing.
Author Keywords: identity management; Online efficacy; politics; privacy; social influence
